content:
Validator 4 is an important edge case.
It makes sure that the clasher is only removing commas with the negative index search routine. If your code just finds which indices it can remove ANY CHARACTER to make the number valid, then it looks like the answer is -7 (remove the last digit). Of course, you can't remove a non-comma to win, so the real answer is "impossible".

There's no test case similar to this though, so I just got 88% on a clash for missing this issue in my code.

I suggest adding a similar test case. Probably just editing an existing one to be similar. Otherwise, it's a fun clash!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: its good but the statement is too long

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Looks good, just that it might take quite long to read through the description and understand it

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good Puzzle

Goal section
* Suggest to mention the term "thousands separator" somewhere, which serves as a minimum explanation of what kind of "comma separation" is expected.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decimal_separator#Digit_grouping

(A more explicit description would be like, a comma should be added from right to left every 3 digits, but I guess that may not be necessary.)

* Please specify that the strings are 0-indexed (some programming languages do not work like that, so specification is needed).

* Please give examples of what the output means. For example,
<<Examples:>>
• An output of {{-2}} means the comma at index {{2}} should be removed.
• An output of {{2}} means a comma should be added before the character at index {{2}}.

* Please clarify what one should choose to output in case of two possible solutions. For example, in test 2, -2 and -1 should both work.

* The last paragraph is not a note. It is an example of "impossible".

Output section
* Please mention the possibility of {{0}}.
* I think the second sentence is not needed.

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement.

Thanks.

Thanks for the feedback, everything should be done.

For your fourth note: I think there is actually one possibility, because "8," could lead to something like "8,000" (according to the comma separation used here), but "8,," would lead to nothing as it's invalid. Let me know if you think I should still explain it.
Thanks for the note. I added a similar testcase which'll prevent it

Perfect! :)
Thanks for being so responsive.
I mean you may remove either the first comma or the second comma in that test. That's why both -1 and -2 can be the valid answers. Or have I misunderstood anything?
I see what you mean, I explained it in the statement now.
